title: What are Prioritization Methods?
description: Master the frameworks used to prioritize features and make trade-off decisions

words.fact: RICE is a prioritization framework that scores features based on four factors: Reach (how many people), Impact (how much effect), Confidence (how certain), and Effort (time required). The score is calculated as (Reach × Impact × Confidence) / Effort. This data-driven approach helps product teams make objective prioritization decisions.

The Kano Model categorizes features into five types based on customer satisfaction: Basic (must-haves), Performance (more is better), Excitement (delighters), Indifferent (don't care), and Reverse (satisfaction decreases). This framework helps teams understand which features will truly delight customers versus those that are simply expected.

Impact measures the degree of positive effect a feature will have on the desired outcome, typically rated on a scale (e.g., 0.25 for minimal to 3 for massive). High-impact features significantly move key metrics like conversion, retention, or revenue. Estimating impact requires understanding user needs and business goals.

Value represents the benefit a feature provides to users or the business. It can be measured in various ways: revenue generated, cost saved, problems solved, or user satisfaction gained. Value-based prioritization ensures teams focus on work that delivers the greatest return on investment and aligns with strategic objectives.

Effort estimation measures the resources (time, people, complexity) required to complete a feature. It's often expressed in story points, person-hours, or t-shirt sizes (S/M/L/XL). Accurate effort estimates help teams balance quick wins with longer-term investments and communicate realistic timelines to stakeholders.

The Urgent vs Important matrix, popularized by Eisenhower, helps distinguish between tasks requiring immediate attention and those contributing to long-term goals. Urgent items demand quick action but may not be strategically important. Effective product managers balance addressing urgent issues while maintaining focus on important strategic initiatives.
